fol.120r
March [To] my L. Treasuror
May it please yo
r
good L. The
Empero
rs
Am-
bassado
r
hath had his Audience of the
states,
who are nowe come together in competent num-
ber. His demaunde was no other, then I have
signified heeretofore,
at his felowe Commissioner
might have
e Pasport of
e states, to come safely
to
e Hage. Howbeit his speeches were quicke
in taxing
e assemblie, for suffering those of
Brus-
sels
, and himself in this place, to attend so longe
w
t
out an answear. There was nothing in wri-
ting delivered by him, nor yet any thing required.
For they are doubtfull what to doe, in regard of
e people, among whome it is thought,
at
e copies
spredde abroade of suche Propositions, will produce
no good effectes. Nevertheles, there are some
men sette a worke, about framing an answear:
whiche will be negative alltogether, and yet
contrived in suche sort, as both it may contene
e reasons of their refusall, to hearcken to those
Ambassado
rs
, and likewise their desire to come
to
a
Pacification. Moreoever, as I suppose, they
will resolve to send their answear, not onely
to
e Empero
r
, but to divers Princes of
e Em-
pire, and also publishe it in print.
They are wholy heere busied, about making pro-
vision to goe into
e feelde: for w
ch
I thinke they
will be ready, w
t
in a moneth at
e furthest.
Howbeit it is not yet notified, w
at
e Provinces
will contribut. If her
Ma
tie
hold her purpose,
to persuade w
t
e states, to imploie their forces
this sommer in the warres of
Fran ce:
and to
fol.120v
reserve no more at home, then for defens
[e of]
their townes, it will be needefull in my
opinion
to attempt it out of hand, and
at
e
King
do
concurre
and
at very earnestly
in
e self same petition. I hav
e im-
parted
e mater
it at large
unto
M
r
Buzenval
,
who
embraced it presently w
t
a very good lik
ing
but perceaving often, as I doe conjecture
that
it would not be pleasing to
Count Maurice
to
whome he would not be but pleasing, I doe
find
him a litle shrinking, and
discoursing
alleaging
again
st it,
alleaging
at
That
e Kinge may receave as gre
at a
benefit by
e exploites of this contrey, as b
y the
use of those men,
at they may lende him
. I
But his arguments
are so feeble, as they
rather seeme to be
sought of sette purpose
then presented unto
him in good discourse
of reas
o
should thinke it very requisit, in regard of
his
backwardnes,
at some letter of charge from
the
kinge, or of advise from
Mons
r
de Nocle
,
were
sent unto him. It is common
ly spoken
heere,
at
e mariage between
Count H
ohenloo
and Count Maurices sister
e
Countesse of
Buren
shall shortly goe forward. And many men
imagine
it will occasion great dissention betwee
n the
two Countes. For
e Countesse complain
eth that
her brother doth oppresse her, in sundrie
great
causes, w
ch
Count Hohenloo will not to
lerate
if he were maried to
e Countesse, as he
openly
professeth. Moreover for these three or
four
yeres,
e cariage and countenance of Co
unt
Maurice towardes him, hath rather bin un
loving
and disdainefull and framed to
depress him,
then respective to his q
a
litie, and
to his
merites
towardes his
father
and sister
he hath done to his father, and to [his sister]
fol.121r
wherat Count Hohenloo hath greatly grieved for a
long time together: and nowe, as it seemeth, by
e
report of those speeches,
at he hath uttered to divers,
will take more knowledge of suche usage. It is
supposed
at
[.]
he hath secret frindes in this
state,
at are of good credit, and enourage him to
this course. I can not
yet
conceave,
at this
privat
divisi
o
hartburning
between them
will growe to
at degree, as to hinder
e proceedinges of
e affaires of
e state: but I am
thorowly persuaded, it may turne her Ma
tie
in time,
to speciall good service, in many of her causes.
I have b
e
earnest this day w
t
e ass
e
bly
about s
o
order to be taken for
e am
e
ding
of their Placcart of C
o
merce of
Spaine,
to
e effect of these notes, w
ch
I receaved fr
o
her Ma
tie
a
d
posed unto th
e
in october
last: wherto by reas
o
of their recesse, and
[.]
no ass
e
blie till nowe, they cold make
me no
a
swear. I have also exhibited
unto th
e
her Ma
ties
letter in
e favo
r
of
my
L. Willughby
,
a
d
a
other lately s
e
t
hither for
e
March
a
ts
of
Middellburgh:
both w
ch
causes, I have solicited w
t
all
c
o
veni
e
t
i
st
a
ce. Assoone as I have
their
a
swear (for they require to th

d it yo
